content: The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows all uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP. Section 2110(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a child who is an, and no exclusion of children with access to high-cost coverage is permitted. The "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" allows uninsured children to be eligible for SCHIP, with no exclusion for children with access to high-cost coverage. Amendments are made to Titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act, replacing "targeted low-income" with "targeted vulnerable." The amendments made by the "SCHIP Expansion Act of 2004" take effect on October 1, 2004, regarding children whose family income exceeds 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN FEDERAL FINANCIAL PARTICIPATION UNDER SCHIP AND MEDICAID FOR STATES WITH SIMPLIFIED ENROLLMENT AND RENEWAL PROCEDURES FOR CHILDREN. The amendment to Section 2105(c)(2) of the Social Security Act increases federal payment for states with simplified enrollment and renewal procedures under SCHIP. The limitation on expenditures for outreach strategies is waived if the State implements the same strategies for children under title XIX. Additionally, the enhanced FMAP for a State is adjusted for a fiscal year. The State's enhanced FMAP for a fiscal year is increased by 5 percentage points for certain expenditures. Outreach strategies include presumptive eligibility and 12-month continuous eligibility for children under title XIX. The State provides automatic renewal of children's eligibility for assistance under title XIX and Medicaid, without asset tests, and redetermination not more than once a year. The State provides presumptive eligibility for children under title XIX and Medicaid, with enhanced Federal medical assistance percentage for outreach strategies. The State offers presumptive eligibility for individuals under title XIX and title XXI, with 12-month continuous eligibility, elimination of asset tests, and passive renewal of assistance. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this section, regarding sections 1902(l)(5) and 1933(d), will take effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to increase funding for SCHIP and eliminates the SCHIP DIP. The amendments take effect on October 1, 2004. SEC. 5 imposes a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not used up their available allotments. The amendment to the Social Security Act imposes a limitation on payments to states with enrollment caps that have not fully expended their available allotments for child health assistance. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows states to establish open enrollment periods for child health assistance applications, effective October 1, 2004. The amendment to the Social Security Act extends Medicaid managed care requirements to SCHIP, effective October 1, 2004.
